terms.definition:
Heart
Blood vessels
Blood

terms.term: Describe the pathway of blood through the heart
terms.definition: Blood enters the heart at the vena cava through the right atrium, then through the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle and out of the heart out the pulmonary artery through the semi-lunar/pulmonary valve. After oxygen is diffused into the bloodstream at the lungs, it returns to the heart through the pulmonary vein into the left atrium and then through the bicuspid valve into the left ventricle. Then out the aorta through the aortic/semi-lunar valve.

terms.term: Describe conduction system of the heart
terms.definition:
Myogenic as generates own impulse. 
Impulse initiated at SA node (in posterior wall of right atrium) = pacemaker 
Impulse travels through atrial walls causing them to contract 
Reaches to AV node in top of septum which delays impulse allowing atria to finish contraction
Travels to bundle of HIS in middle septum
splits into bundle branches 
Travels up and around walls of ventricles via purkinje fibres causing them to contract 
Ventricles relax and fill with blood until next impulse is initiated from SA node
Mechanical events of a single heartbeat
72 bpm
Diastole, atrial systole , ventricular systole
Relaxation of heart, fills with blood lasts 0.5 secs
Contraction of atria when blood is forced into ventricles
Contraction of ventricles forcing blood out of heart into body

terms.term: Describe the events of the cardiac cycle
terms.definition: Diastole lasts for 0.5 secs as the heart relaxes and fills with blood. Pressure increases in the atria as tricuspid / bicuspid valves remain shut until blood is forced into the ventricles during atrial systole when pressure gets too high and atria contract. Ventricles then contract to force blood out of heart via semi-lunar valves.

terms.term: What does no electrical impulse cause
terms.definition: Diastole
Volume of blood leaving left ventricle per minute (L/min)
Volume of blood leaving the heart per beat (mL/beat)
Amount of times heart beats per minute (bpm)

terms.term: Relationship between Q SV and HR
terms.definition: Q=SVxHR
Term for resting HR of below 60bpm

terms.term: Average HR of untrained performer (rest, sub max, max)
Average SV of untrained performer (rest, s-m, m)
terms.definition: 70, 120, 120 (peaks at sum-maximal exercise)

terms.term: Why does SV peak at sub max exercise ?
terms.definition: Because the heart can only pump so much in one beat, after that cardiac output increases as a result of HR increase

terms.term:
Average cardiac output for untrained performer
Rest, s-m, m
Describe Hr changes during 3k/sub max run
terms.definition:
AR due to release of adrenaline 
Rapid increase to meet demand of O2 needed, HR spikes suddenly as exercise begins after rest 
Steady state: HR met demand of 02 required or exercising at a constant speed/intensity.
Rapid decrease: exercise stops and demand for o2 decreases

terms.term: Describe HR changes during high intensity exercise eg. 400m run
terms.definition:
Anticipatory rise- adrenaline 
Rapid increase - exercise suddenly begins from rest, iuncxreased 02 demand 
Slower increase: due to increasing pace/increased 02 demand as excericse increases in intensity 
Rapid decrease as excerpts use stops 02 no longer needed in such high demand 
Slower decrease to resting hr

terms.term: What happens to cardiac output during exercise
terms.definition: Increases and plateaus during maximal exercise

terms.term: What happened to SV during exercise
terms.definition: Increases until sub max then plateaus
Starlings law
‘The force of ventricular contraction is dependent on the length of muscle fibres in the heart wall’
Amount of blood in the right or left ventricle after filling (diastole)

terms.term: Describe the events of starlings law in increasing stroke volume.
terms.definition: Increased venous return causes greater end diastolic volume which causes heart muscle to stretch as its elastic. This results in a more powerful contraction resulting in a greater ejection fraction which results in greater stroke volume.

terms.term: Which nervous system controls heart rate
terms.definition: Autonomic

terms.term: What are the 3 main control mechanisms which determine the action of the CCC
terms.definition:
Neural
Intrinsic 
Hormonal

Chemoreceptors 
Proprioreceptors 
Baroreceptors
In joints detects motor activity/movement
Detect changes in blood acidity (CO2 and lactic acid)
Detects changes in blood pressure

terms.term: How do chemoreceptors cause HR to increase
terms.definition: As exercises begins, chemoreceptors detect an increase in blood acidity (more co2 and lactic acid) and informs the CCC (in medulla oblongata). An impulse is sent via the accelerator nerve tot eh SA node to stimulate more electrical impulses to be generated at a higher frequency, resulting in increased HR.

Temperature increase during exercise causes decreased viscosity of blood, allowing more blood to enter in the heart quicker to be pumped out faster. 
Temperature increases nerve impulse transmission (CCC->SA). 
Venous return increases, increasing stretch in ventricle walls, increases force of ventricular contraction and therefore SV.
Adrenal glands release adrenaline/noradrenaline. Increases force of contraction and stroke volume, heart rate increases.

terms.term: Sympathetic nervous system impact on HR
terms.definition: Increases

terms.term: ParaSympathetic nervous system impact on HR
terms.definition: Decreases

terms.term: Describe how the NS controls HR
terms.definition:
Accelerator nerve - when stimulated as part of Sympathetic NS, increases HR 
Goes between medulla oblongata and SA node

Vagus nerve - when stimulated as part of Parasypathetic NS, decreases HR Goes between medulla oblongata and SA node

terms.term: What is the vascular system made of
terms.definition: Blood vessels

Transport nutrients eg. O2 and glucose 
Protect and fight diseases
Regulate temperature

Thick walls to withstand high pressure
elastic fibres to stretch with each surge of high pressure without tearing
Interior walls have more smooth muscle than veins do allowing change size as pressure changes during exercise.

Smallest artery branch.
Greater amounts of smooth muscle allowing them to vasoconstrict and dilate easily in order to regulate blood flow and maintain BP
Connects arteries and capillaries

Near surface usually
Valves to prevent backlfow as low pressure 
Less elastic fibres/smooth muscles bc withstand less pressure.
Thin walls leads to blood pooling as they can widen (this affects venous return )

Smallest vein branches = venules. 
Transport blood away from the capillary beds into veins.

One cell thick 
Site of gaseous exchange - completely coveres muscles (efficient)
allows food and oxygen to pass out of body cells and co2 / waste products into bloodstream 
Moist 
Short diffusion pathways
Control blood flow through capillary networks
Return of blood to the right side of the heart

terms.term: Why does VR need to be assisted ?
terms.definition: Because venous pressure is a lot lower than arterial pressure

terms.term: What are the 5 mechanisms assisting VR
terms.definition:
Pocket valves 
Skeletal muscle pump
Respiratory pump
Smooth muscle 
Gravity

Smooth muscle 
Gravity

terms.term: Outline how pocket valves assist VR
terms.definition: Veins contain pocket valves which are one way system, preventing backflow. Prevent heavy legs and ensure blood always flows towards the heart instead of backwards.

terms.term: How do pocket valves and skeletal muscle pump work together
terms.definition: Valves are assisted by skeletal muscle in maintaining one directional flow.

terms.term: Describe how skeletal muscle pump aids VR
terms.definition: Contraction of skeletal muscles squeezes veins with thin walls, forcing blood back to the heart faster with greater force.

terms.term: Describe how respiratory pump aids VR
terms.definition: Expiration increases pressure in lungs which compresses respiratory veins, forcing blood back to heart. Inspiration flattens the diaphragm and squeezes abdominal organs against5 veins also forcing blood back to the heart. This all increases VR.

terms.term: Describe how smooth muscle aids VR
terms.definition: Veins have smooth muscle which helps them venoconsctrict and venodilate. The brain send signals through the ANS to the smooth muscle from the vasomotor centre. Venocontriction decreases lumen size, forcing blood back to the heart faster/with greater force.
Assists blood flow back to heart from the upper body as blood flows alongside the pull of gravity.

terms.term: Why is skeletal muscle pump the most important mechanism which increases VR?
terms.definition: Because not only does it squeeze veins through contraction of muscles, forcing more blood towards the heart at a faster rate with greater force, it works alongside pocket valves (helps to maintain one directional flow) and gravity (because gravity hinders VR from lower body so skeletal muscle pump helps it get from lower body to heart quicker, increasing VR).

terms.term: Why do sports like swimming have a higher Vr dueieng exceecise than running ?
terms.definition: Because swimmers are usually in a supine/lying down/horizontal position, so they have a higher VR during excericse because their bodies aren’t working against gravity so much.

terms.term: Describe the difference between blood distribution at rest and during exercise
terms.definition: At rest, blood is distributed evenly with most blood going to vital organs such as the liver,brain,kidneys and digestive system. During exercise, blood goes almost 90% to muscles and decreases to organs (except for brain Which remains the same always).
Redistribution of blood during exercise

terms.term: Explain the distribution of blood flow during exercise
terms.definition:
Blood flow is decreased to areas of body which don’t immediately require as much o2 as normal, eg. Digestive system, liver, kidneys
Blood flow is increased to skeletal muscles which requires lots more o2 for respiration during exercise
The narrowing of the arteries via smooth muscle or the contraction of pre-capillary sphincters which prevent blood flow through surrounding capillaries
Widening of arteries via smooth muscle or the relaxation of pre capillary sphincters which allow blood to pass through surrounding capillaries.

terms.term: How is blood redistributed during exercise
terms.definition:
Through vascular shunt mechanims
Pre capillary sphincters are located in the arterioles. Rings of muscle which either relax to increase blood flow through to capillaries or contract to reduce blood flow through to capillaries. (Vasocntronsticton) vasodilation
Towards muscles, arterioles vasodilate to allow more blood and therefore oxygen to the muscle cells for respiration 
Towards non-vital eg. Digestive organs, arterioles vasocontrict to reduce blood flow therefore allowing extra to go to muscles

terms.term: What controls the redistribution of blood
terms.definition: Vasomotor control centre (VCC) located in medulla oblongata.
Constant slight state of constriction of smooth muscle in arterial walls.

terms.term: How does the VCC control the vascular shunt mechanism
terms.definition: Stimulates sympNS via nerves in smooth muscle of arterial walls, causing vasoconstriction at arterioles / pre-capillary sphincters to unimportant areas eg. Liver/kidneys and vasodilation to increase blood flow to active muscles.

terms.term: Describe the location of the AV node
terms.definition: Right side of the heart between the right and left ventricles. Above bundle of HIS

terms.term: Explain how the conduction system control diastole
terms.definition: When there is no electrical impulse, the heart can relax and fill with blood.
